abstract.text: Creates a PDF graphics context that targets a file at the specified path.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A POSIX-style path string identifying the location of the resulting PDF file. The specified path may be relative or a full path name. If a file does not exist at the specified path, one is created; otherwise, the contents of any existing file are deleted. The directories in the path must exist.

A rectangle that specifies the default size and location of PDF pages. (This value is used as the default media box for each new page.) The origin of the rectangle should typically be (0, 0). Specifying an empty rectangle (
) sets the default page size to 8.5 by 11 inches (612 by 792 points).

A dictionary that specifies additional information to be associated with the PDF file. You can use these keys to specify additional metadata and security information for the PDF, such as the author of the PDF or the password for accessing it. The keys in this dictionary are the same keys you pass to the
function and are described in the Auxiliary Dictionary Keys section of
. The dictionary is retained by the new context, so on return you may safely release it.
Specify
if you do not want to associate any additional information with the PDF document.
if the PDF context was created successfully or
if it was not.

After creating the graphics context, this function makes it the current drawing context. Any subsequent drawing commands are therefore captured and turned into PDF data. When you are done drawing, you must call the
function to close the PDF graphics context.

You can use all of the same drawing routines that you would normally use to draw the contents of your application. However, before you issue any drawing commands to a PDF context, you must start a new page by calling the
or
function. You can also use these functions to define additional pages later.
After creating it, you can get the PDF context using the
function.

abstract.text: Creates a PDF graphics context.
A type of  for drawing PDF content.
A rectangle constant with location `(0,0)`, and width and height of 0. The zero rectangle is equivalent to `CGRectMake(0,0,0,0)`.
A false value.
A true value.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Creates a jump destination in the current page.
Creates a PDF graphics context that targets the specified mutable data object.
Creates a PDF graphics context that targets a file at the specified path.
Marks the beginning of a new page in a PDF context and configures it using default values.
Marks the beginning of a new page in a PDF context and configures it using the specified custom values.
Closes a PDF graphics context and pops it from the current context stack.
Returns the current graphics context.
Returns the current page bounds.
Links a rectangular area on the current page to the specified jump destination.
Links a rectangular area on the current page to the specified URL.
A structure that contains the location and dimensions of a rectangle.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A type-erased hashable value.

inlineContent.text: A POSIX-style path string identifying the location of the resulting PDF file. The specified path may be relative or a full path name. If a file does not exist at the specified path, one is created; otherwise, the contents of any existing file are deleted. The directories in the path must exist.

A rectangle that specifies the default size and location of PDF pages. (This value is used as the default media box for each new page.) The origin of the rectangle should typically be (0, 0). Specifying an empty rectangle (
) sets the default page size to 8.5 by 11 inches (612 by 792 points).

A dictionary that specifies additional information to be associated with the PDF file. You can use these keys to specify additional metadata and security information for the PDF, such as the author of the PDF or the password for accessing it. The keys in this dictionary are the same keys you pass to the
function and are described in the Auxiliary Dictionary Keys section of
. The dictionary is retained by the new context, so on return you may safely release it.
Specify
if you do not want to associate any additional information with the PDF document.
if the PDF context was created successfully or
if it was not.

value.text: A static, plain-text Unicode string object.
